qas.question: Which Executive Order first contained the phrase "affirmative action"?
Who chaired the committee created by Executive Order 10925?
Who co - authored the executive order?
What was the alternative phrase to "affirmative action" that was being considered?
What was the main reason that "affirmative action" was chosen over "positive action"?
Which Executive Order didn't contain the phrase "affirmative action"?
Who chaired the committee destroyed by Executive Order 10925?
Who co - authored the non-executive order?
What was the alternative phrase to "non-affirmative action" that was being considered?
What was the main reason that "non-affirmative action" was chosen over "positive action"?

context: The first time "affirmative action" is used by the federal government concerning race is in President John F. Kennedy's <a0_0><b5_0>Executive Order 10925<b5_0/><a0_0/>, which was chaired by <a1_0><b6_0>Vice President Johnson<b6_0/><a1_0/>. At Johnson's inaugural ball in Texas, he met with a young black lawyer, <a2_0><b7_0>Hobart Taylor Jr<b7_0/>.<a2_0/>, and gave him the task to co-author the executive order. He wanted a phrase that "gave a sense of positivity to performance under the order." He was torn between the words "<a3_0><b8_0>positive action<b8_0/><a3_0/>" and "affirmative action," and selected the later due to its <a4_0><b9_0>alliterative quality<b9_0/><a4_0/>. The term "active recruitment" started to be used as well. This order, albeit heavily worked up as a significant piece of legislation, in reality carried little actual power. The scope was limited to a couple hundred defense contractors, leaving nearly $7.5 billion in federal grants and loans unsupervised.:60
